thread.title: Senex cashes in on GLNG promise
thread.title_full: Senex cashes in on GLNG promise | Business News | Business and Finance News | | The Advertiser

author: Valerina Changarathil
title: Senex cashes in on GLNG promise
text:
OIL and gas producer Senex Energy is the first to cash in on the long-held promise attached to gas-rich areas in the vicinity of the Santos-operated Queensland LNG plant.
Senex has signed “transformational” agreements with GLNG’s participants, industry majors Santos, Total, PETRONAS and KOGAS.
The Brisbane company will receive $42 million by December this year for the sale of its 77 sq km Maisey block that sits within GLNG’s Roma coal seam gas acreage.
It will also supply up to 50 terajoules of gas per day for 20 years to GLNG from its proposed Western Surat Gas project in the Surat Basin, due for final investment decision in 2017 and tipped to cost several hundred million dollars.
Senex also gets access to GLNG data and infrastructure, which could potentially derisk and accelerate its project.
“This is a natural relationship given our acreage sits adjacent to GLNG’s Roma fields,” said Senex managing director Ian Davies who was happy to “share good news” after reporting a FY15 net loss of $80.6 million last month.
“We know GLNG needs the gas and we are looking at building a valuable and material east coast gas business.
“The derisking of the Surat Basin will help us come back to the Cooper Basin without distraction, where we have invested a lot.”
“Today we are confident of our resources, have secured our market, and have agreements to utilise infrastructure - this is building into a great project for Senex.”
Nearly 21 million Senex shares changed hands yesterday- less than the mysterious 37 million last Friday - to close 24 per cent stronger at 15.5c.
